      <script type="text/javascript">
        window.__PRELOADED_STATE__ = {"abstracts":{"content":[{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"sect0005"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"__text__","_":"The currently prevailing single complexing agent-dominated sol-gel technologies for Na"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"V"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"(PO"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"4"},{"#name":"__text__","_":")"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" (NVP) cathodes in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) always result in limited modification effects, especially in regards to the particle size of NVP and the quality of carbon coatings. Herein, we report a citric acid and glycine co-complexed strategy for fabricating carbon-coated NVP. It creates a favorable synergy for optimizing the microstructure and electrochemical performance of the NVP cathode. The introduction of glycine in citric acid not only decreases the solution viscosity for facilitated metal-ion diffusion, but also induces the self-construction of a 3D network through heteromolecular hydrogen bonds. The optimized carbon-coated NVP by co-complexing of citric acid and glycine (named as NVP/CG-5.0) presents distinctly decreased particle size, improved dispersity and moderate carbon coating thickness of ∼2 nm. It also features a large specific surface area of 44.4 m"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" with rich mesopores. Impressively, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode exhibits substantially improved electrochemical performance, such as the elevated specific capacity of 108.3 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" with high initial Coulombic efficiency (95.2%), high capacity retention of 81.3% after 2000 cycles at 2 C and excellent rate performance (88.2 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" at 20.0 C). Furthermore, the assembled NVP/CG-5.0║hard carbon full battery also exhibits superior electrochemical performance, suggesting the great potential of the co-complexed strategy for developing high-performance NVP cathodes in SIBs."}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"sp0040"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"abs0010"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"ab0010","class":"author"},"#name":"abstract"},{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"sect0010"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Highlights"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"label","_":"•"},{"$$":[{"#name":"__text__","_":"Citric article."}]}],"floats":[],"footnotes":[],"attachments":[]},"crossMark":{"isOpen":false},"domainConfig":{"assetRoute":"https://sdfestaticassets-eu-west-1.sciencedirectassets.com/prod/fa1c8b2301a14e2a58982c67ebe341e7af7fd8fc","cdnAssetsHost":"https://sdfestaticassets-eu-west-1.sciencedirectassets.com"},"downloadIssue":{"openOnPageLoad":false,"isOpen":false,"downloadCapOpen":false,"articles":[],"selected":[]},"enrichedContent":{"tableOfContents":false,"researchData":{"hasResearchData":false,"dataProfile":{},"openData":{},"mendeleyData":{},"databaseLinking":{}},"geospatialData":{"attachments":[]},"interactiveCaseInsights":{},"virtualMicroscope":{}},"entitledRecommendations":{"openOnPageLoad":false,"isOpen":false,"articles":[],"selected":[],"currentPage":1,"totalPages":1},"exam":{},"helpText":{"keyDates":{"html":"<div class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. For any questions on your own submission or other questions related to publishing an article, <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://service.elsevier.com/app/phone/supporthub/publishing\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">contact our Researcher support team.</span></span></a></p></div>","title":"What do these dates mean?"}},"glossary":{},"issueNavigation":{"previous":{},"next":{}},"linkingHubLinks":{},"metrics":{"metricGroup":{"citations":[],"captures":[],"mentions":[],"socialMedia":[]},"isLoading":false,"error":false,"hasMetrics":false},"preview":{},"rawtext":"","recommendations":{},"references":{},"referenceLinks":{"internal":[],"internalLoaded":false,"external":[]},"refersTo":{},"referredToBy":{},"relatedContent":{"isModal":false,"isOpenSpecialIssueArticles":false,"isOpenVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false,"isOpenRecommendations":true,"isOpenSubstances":true,"citingArticles":[false,false,false,false,false,false],"recommendations":[false,false,false,false,false,false]},"seamlessAccess":{},"specialIssueArticles":{},"substances":{},"supplementaryFilesData":[],"tableOfContents":{"showEntitledTocLinks":true},"tail":{},"transientError":{"isOpen":false},"sidePanel":{"openState":1},"viewConfig":{"articleFeature":{"aiNavigation":true},"pathPrefix":""},"virtualSpecialIssue":{"showVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false},"usageProps":{"itemStage":"S300","isAip":false,"tombAip":"0","sample":false},"userCookiePreferences":{"STRICTLY_NECESSARY":true,"PERFORMANCE":true,"FUNCTIONAL":true,"TARGETING":false}};

icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abs0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0045"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">Citric acid and glycine co-complexed strategy is developed for Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">A strong synergy between the two complexing agents is demonstrated.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Prominent improvement in particle size, dispersity and carbon coating is realized.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">The optimized composite exhibits greatly enhanced cycling stability and rate ability.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab0010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abs0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0040">The currently prevailing single complexing agent-dominated sol-gel technologies for Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> (NVP) cathodes in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) always result in limited modification effects, especially in regards to the particle size of NVP and the quality of carbon coatings. Herein, we report a <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a><span> and glycine co-complexed strategy for fabricating carbon-coated NVP. It creates a favorable synergy for optimizing the microstructure and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span><span> of the NVP cathode. The introduction of glycine in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a><span> not only decreases the <a href="/topics/engineering/viscosity-solution" title="Learn more about solution viscosity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solution viscosity</a> for facilitated metal-ion diffusion, but also induces the self-construction of a 3D network through heteromolecular </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrogen-bond" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonds</a><span>. The optimized carbon-coated NVP by co-complexing of <a href="/topics/chemistry/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a><span> and glycine (named as NVP/CG-5.0) presents distinctly decreased particle size, improved dispersity and moderate carbon coating thickness of ∼2 nm. It also features a large specific <a href="/topics/chemistry/surface-area" title="Learn more about surface area from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface area</a> of 44.4 m</span></span></span></span></span><sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup><span> with rich <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a>. Impressively, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode exhibits substantially improved electrochemical performance, such as the elevated specific capacity of 108.3 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> with high initial Coulombic efficiency (95.2%), high capacity retention of 81.3% after 2000 cycles at 2 C and excellent rate performance (88.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup><span> at 20.0 C). Furthermore, the assembled NVP/CG-5.0║hard carbon full <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> also exhibits superior electrochemical performance, suggesting the great potential of the co-complexed strategy for developing high-performance NVP cathodes in SIBs.</span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0925838824007266"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0925838824006285"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0005" class="keyword"><span>Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></span></div><div id="key0010" class="keyword"><span>Sol-gel method</span></div><div id="key0015" class="keyword"><span>Complexing agent</span></div><div id="key0020" class="keyword"><span>Synergistic effect</span></div><div id="key0025" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0005"><h2 id="sect0025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span><span><span>The excessive consumption of traditional <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/fossil-fuel" title="Learn more about fossil fuels from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fossil fuels</a> in industries leads to a series of environmental pollution problems and </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/greenhouse-effect" title="Learn more about greenhouse effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">greenhouse effect</a><span>. In this context, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/renewable-energy" title="Learn more about renewable energies from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">renewable energies</a> usher in a thriving development opportunity. However, their unstable energy supply promotes large-scale </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-system" title="Learn more about energy storage systems from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage systems</a> (EESs) becoming increasingly indispensable </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a><span>. Benefitting from the abundant reserves and low price of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> salts, rechargeable sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with similar operation principles to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been considered as one of the most promising candidates for EES applications </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a><span><span>. However, the practical application of SIBs remains challenging due to some unresolved issues. Typically, the larger atomic radius of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> (0.098 nm) than that of lithium (0.069 nm) makes the currently prevailing </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode materials</a> of LIBs inapplicable for Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> insertion/extraction. Moreover, the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-structure" title="Learn more about electrode structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode structure</a> is prone to collapse in repeated charge/discharge processes </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a><span>. Meanwhile, the larger <a href="/topics/engineering/ionic-radius" title="Learn more about ionic radius from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic radius</a> also results in the slow diffusion of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> in the bulk of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/active-matter" title="Learn more about active matter from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">active matter</a>. Thus, it is urgently necessary to explore suitable electrode materials for high-performance SIBs.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about Cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cathode materials</a><span> are vital components in SIBs, accounting for ∼26% of the total bill of material cost. The preoccupant cathode materials that have commercialization application potentials are layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a>, polyanionic compounds and Prussian blue analogs </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>. Among them, sodium vanadium phosphate (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span>, NVP), as a typical representative of polyanionic compounds, has drawn intensive attention due to its unique <a href="/topics/chemistry/nasicons" title="Learn more about NASICON from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NASICON</a> structure featuring with a three-dimensional skeleton </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>. The open channels facilitate fast ion conductivity, making NVP a competitive candidate for high-rate cathode materials. Nevertheless, NVP has similar problem to other polyanionic compounds. Because VO<sub>6</sub> is isolated by PO<sub>4</sub> groups, electrons cannot conduct along V-O-V, resulting in low intrinsic conductivity and inferior electrochemical redox reversibility <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><span>Intensive researches have been focused on the improvement of <a href="/topics/engineering/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> by means of various strategies, such as the substitution of V sites through heterogeneous cation doping </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, surface modification by carbon coatings <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, incorporation with carbon matrices and morphology engineering <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a><span><span><span>. Among them, carbon <a href="/topics/materials-science/coating-technology" title="Learn more about coating technologies from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating technologies</a><span> have received much attention because they can generate conductive components in-situ on the grain surface and restrain the sintering of NVP particles. Sol-gel methods, which have been widely considered as one of the most effective routes to tune the microstructure of <a href="/topics/materials-science/functional-material" title="Learn more about functional materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">functional materials</a> by complexing with </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a>, are usually employed to synthesize carbon-coated NVP composites. For example, Zhou et al. used </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a><span> as both the carbon source and <a href="/topics/engineering/complexing-agent" title="Learn more about complexing agent from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">complexing agent</a><span> to form a conductive layer of 7.3 nm on the surface of NVP. By improving the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> and agglomeration behavior of NVP particles, a long cycling life of 2000 cycles at 10 C with capacity retention of 78.3% was achieved </span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a><span>. C. Park et al. synthesized a 3D porous NVP hybrid structure with a <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about carbon layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon layer</a><span> of ∼5 nm using a modified <a href="/topics/chemistry/oxalic-acid" title="Learn more about oxalic acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxalic acid</a> sol-gel method, which contributed to a high specific capacity of 116.9 mAh g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> at 1 C and superior long-term cycling stability over 6000 cycles (77% capacity retention) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a><span>. When researchers focus their attention on the elevation of electrical conductivity, the <a href="/topics/chemistry/quality-control" title="Learn more about quality control from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">quality control</a><span> of the microstructure of carbon coatings (e.g. uniformity and layer thickness) and the effect of particle dimension diminution are critical for achieving excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. After browsing the related literatures that fabricated carbon-coated NVP by sol-gel methods, it is found that the researchers always employ a single complexing agent to tune the microstructure of NVP, which has been proven to achieve limited improvement in electrochemical performance, especially in the rate capability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a><span>. The reason for these unsatisfactory modification effects could be the quite limited adjustment ability of a single <a href="/topics/chemistry/organic-acid" title="Learn more about organic acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">organic acid</a> for the formation of moderate interactions between organic molecules and V</span><sup>3+</sup><span> ions. Moreover, when the carbon species from a single carbon source are in the nucleation stage, they have a large surface <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/gibbs-free-energy" title="Learn more about Gibbs free energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Gibbs free energy</a>. This state inevitably leads to thermodynamic agglomeration at high temperatures, thereafter making the regulation of carbon layer uniformity and thickness difficult </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. In addition, according to the literatures, the enhancement of cyclic stability and rate performance of NVP by carbon coatings seems thermodynamically incompatible <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. A dilemma usually exists that a too thin carbon coating with friable structure cannot provide structural support for repeated extraction/insertion of Na<sup>+</sup> and makes the electrode difficult to maintain structural and cycling stability. While too thick carbon layers severely hinder convenient electrolyte penetration and fast ion migration, as well as the realization of high specific capacity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. Based on these analyses, the search for suitable multicomplexing agent-involved sol-gel systems to create a satisfactory synergy in microstructure optimization of NVP may be significant for prominently enhanced comprehensive electrochemical performance. To our knowledge, there are still few explorations on this aspect to date.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span><span><span>In this work, we proposed a co-complexing sol-gel strategy by combining <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a><span> and glycine to develop nitrogen-doped carbon-coated NVP (NVP/CG) composites. Very different from the commonly adopted single complexing agent-dominated process, the well-designed dual-complexing agent system has distinctive advantages to improve the microstructure and electrochemical performance of NVP. When glycine is added to <a href="/topics/chemistry/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a> system, with the help of the </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/hydrophilicity" title="Learn more about hydrophilic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrophilic</a><span><span> bonds between the two complexing agents in aqueous solution, the free <a href="/topics/engineering/anions-and-cation" title="Learn more about anions and cations from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anions and cations</a> can be trapped by the end groups to control the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/grain-size" title="Learn more about grain size from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">grain size</a> growth. And the hetero three-dimensional network structure formed by their bonding will facilitate more uniform conductive carbon layer with controllable thickness on the NVP’s surface after </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a><span><span>. By tuning the feed ratio of citric acid and glycine, the optimized NVP/CG composite (named as NVP/CG-5.0) exhibits substantially enhanced reversible specific capacity, long-term cycling stability and rate performance compared to the control materials prepared with the single complexing agent of citric acid and glycine separately. Remarkably, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode retains high capacity retention of 81.3% after 2000 charge/discharge cycles at a <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 2 C. Even at a </span><a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current density</a> of 20 C, the electrode still releases an attractive reversible capacity of 88.2 mAh g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> with high rate capacity retention of 81.0%. The superior performance demonstrates the fantastic modification effect by dual-complexing agents for optimizing the microstructure and elevating the sodium-storage performance of NVP cathode materials.</div></section><section id="sec0010"><h2 id="sect0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="sec0015"><h3 id="sect0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Preparation of the NVP/CG composites</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0050">As schematically depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>, the NVP/CG composites were prepared by a sol-gel method with <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a> and glycine as cocomplexing agents. First, 4 mmol NH</span><sub>4</sub>VO<sub>3</sub> and 6 mmol NaH<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>·2 H<sub>2</sub>O were weighed (molar ratio of 2:3), and NH<sub>4</sub>VO<sub>3</sub><span><span> was then added to a beaker containing 60 ml <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deionized water</a> and continuously stirred at 70 °C for 15 min. Subsequently, 11.0 mmol of glycine and 2.2 mmol of </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a> (a mole ratio of 5:1) and NaH</span><sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>·2 H<sub>2</sub>O were added in turn to the above solution, and continuously heated and stirred. In this step, V<sup>5+</sup> was reduced to V<sup>3+</sup><span>. When heated until the <a href="/topics/engineering/precursor-solution" title="Learn more about precursor solution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">precursor solution</a><span> became gelatinous, the beaker was transferred to a vacuum oven at 80 °C and further baked for 12 h. The ground sample was then transferred to a tubular furnace, preheated at 350 °C for 3 h and calcined at 800 °C for 5 h under <a href="/topics/engineering/ar-atmosphere" title="Learn more about Ar atmosphere from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ar atmosphere</a> (heating rate: 5 °C min</span></span><sup>−1</sup><span><span>). After natural cooling, the NVP/CG-5.0 composite was obtained. For comparison, the single <a href="/topics/chemistry/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a> or glycine was employed as the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/complexing-agent" title="Learn more about complexing agent from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">complexing agent</a> to synthesize NVP composites by using the same experimental method above, which were denoted as NVP/C composite and NVP/G composite, respectively. Additionally, to further investigate the effect of the additive amount of glycine, two control samples with glycine/citric acid ratios of 2.5:1 and 10:1 were synthesized, which were recorded as NVP/CG-2.5 and NVP/CG-10, respectively.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr1.jpg" height="290" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (134KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (134KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="sp0005"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. The schematic diagram for the synthesis process of NVP/CG composites by a sol-gel method with citric acid and glycine as cocomplexing agents.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec0020"><h3 id="sect0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span><span>The <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about phase composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phase composition</a> and crystal structure were measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker, Germany) with Cu-Kα (λ=1.54056 Å). The carbon content of the samples was obtained using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, NetzschSTA449C) under an air atmosphere at the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/rate-of-heating" title="Learn more about heating rate of from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heating rate of</a> 10 °C min</span><sup>−1</sup><span>. The morphologies and texture of the NVP composites was visualized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM7001F) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (TEM, JEM2010). The composition of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite was determined by energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The N</span><sub>2</sub><span> adsorption/desorption tests on a <a href="/topics/materials-science/porosimetry" title="Learn more about porosimetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porosimetry</a><span><span> system (ASAP 2020) were performed to investigate the pore and specific surface information. The carbon components were characterized by <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a> (Renishaw RM2000 Confocal) at a wavelength of 532 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ThermoescalAB 250, Al Kα, hν = 1486.6 eV) was used to analyze the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/elemental-composition" title="Learn more about elemental composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental composition</a> and atomic valence on surface.</span></span></div></section><section id="sec0025"><h3 id="sect0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span><span>The electrochemical behaviors of the samples were evaluated by assembling coin-type half cells (CR2025) with <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> metal foils as the counter/reference electrodes. The active material, Super P and <a href="/topics/chemistry/polyvinylidene-fluoride" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene fluoride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene fluoride</a><span> (PVDF) were uniformly mixed in N-methyl pyrrolidone at a mass ratio of 7.0:1.5:1.5, and then coated on <a href="/topics/chemistry/aluminum" title="Learn more about aluminum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum</a> foil, which was dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the foil was cut into </span></span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/disk-electrode" title="Learn more about electrode disks from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode disks</a> with a diameter of 14 mm, and the loading amount of active material was 1.8–2.0 mg·cm</span><sup>−2</sup><span>. A <a href="/topics/chemistry/glass-fiber" title="Learn more about glass fiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glass fiber</a> felt (Whatman GF/D) and 1 M NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span> dissolved in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate/ethyl methyl carbonate (volume ratio of 1:1:1) with 5% fluoroethylene carbonate were used as the separator and electrolyte, respectively. The galvanostatic charge-discharge tests were carried out using a <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> testing system (LAND CT 2001A, Wuhan), and the voltage window ranged from 2.2 to 4.0 V (vs. Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>/Na). <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) tests (scan rate: 0.1 mV s</span><sup>−1</sup><span>) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a><span> (EIS) tests (frequency range: 100 kHz∼0.01 Hz, amplitude: 5 mV) were conducted on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660E, Shanghai). The full cell was assembled by coupling the NVP/CG-5.0 composite and a commercial hard carbon (YHC-1, BAISIGE Co., Ltd.) as the <a href="/topics/engineering/anodes-and-cathode" title="Learn more about cathode and anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode and anode</a> materials, respectively. The anode disks were prepared by casting the mixture of 80 wt% hard carbon, 10 wt% super P and 10 wt% PVDF on a Cu foil. The cathode/anode mass loading ratio was approximate 1.9.</span></span></div></section></section><section id="sec0030"><h2 id="sect0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec0035"><h3 id="sect0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Comparative study for the microstructures of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG composites</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">TGA curves of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites tested in an air atmosphere are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a. The mass loss of the three samples at 50–200 °C is mainly due to the removal of crystalline water inside the materials. Above 200 °C, the weight of the samples continuously decreases with the rising temperature, and the mass loss reaches the highest level at ∼470 °C. The distinct weight loss is attributed to carbon consumption by oxygen and the escape of gaseous products <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span>. Basing on the mass variation in this stage, the carbon content in the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites is approximately estimated to be 2.6%, 3.0% and 6.9%, respectively. It is noted that the carbon content in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite is obviously higher than that of the other two counterpart samples. The behavior reflects the existence of a strong interaction between citric acid and glycine during the complexation process, which creates a beneficial effect for maintaining high carbon yield after thermal annealing. The detailed synergistic mechanism of citric acid and glycine will be elucidated later. As the temperature exceeded ∼470 °C, the weight of all samples slightly increases and then remains stable ascribing to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> of the NVP components </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr2.jpg" height="511" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (432KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (432KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="sp0010"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. (a) TGA curves and (b) <a href="/topics/engineering/x-ray-diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites. (c) The Rietveld-refined XRD pattern of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. (d) The crystal structure diagram of NVP.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span><span>The <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about phase compositions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phase compositions</a> of the three NVP composites were determined by </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction-analysis" title="Learn more about XRD analyses from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD analyses</a>. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b, the diffraction peaks of all samples are analogous in shape with high intensity. The indexed peaks of (012), (104), (113), (024), (211), (116) and other planes are in good agreement with the standard structure of rhombohedral NVP (JCPDS No. 053–0018) without additional impurity peaks, suggesting the high purity of the as-synthesized samples <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a><span><span>. Notably, the peak intensity of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite is significantly lower and broader than that of the NVP/C and NVP/G composites. The distinctive diffraction behavior would be mainly rooted from the particle size difference of NVP in the three composites, a fact of which can be further verified by the morphology observation later. In detail, the particle size of NVP is influenced by the distinct complexation effects of different complexing agents. The high diffraction peak intensity and narrow peak width of the NVP/C and NVP/G composites signify that the single complexing agent of citric acid or glycine has a weak regulating function for grain nucleation and growth, while the combination of the two complexing agents creates a positive synergy for achieving the smaller particle size of NVPs. The <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystallite" title="Learn more about crystallite from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallite</a> size of NVP in the composites was estimated by the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/scherrer-equation" title="Learn more about Scherrer equation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Scherrer equation</a>. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a><span>, the smallest crystalline size for the NVP/CG-5.0 composite also resulted in the weaker diffraction peaks. The crystalline structure of the as-obtained NVPs was further investigated by the Rietveld-refinement of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a>. The results depicted in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a><span> show that the NVP crystals in the composites have a rhomb-shaped structure assigning to a <a href="/topics/chemistry/hexagonal-space-group" title="Learn more about hexagonal crystal system from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hexagonal crystal system</a> with the space group of R-3c. The fitted cell parameters for the NVP/CG-5.0 composite are listed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>, and the results are consistent with the reported data <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>. The corresponding NVP crystal consists of six NVP single cells. Each [V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>3</sub> unit is formed by two VO<sub>6</sub><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/octahedral-crystal" title="Learn more about octahedra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">octahedra</a> and three PO</span><sub>4</sub> tetrahedra connected by oxygen atoms on a common angle in the Z-axis direction (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">To investigate the morphology difference of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites, SEM observation was performed. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2a</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>a show that the NVP/C composite presents an agglomerated bulk morphology where uneven NVP particles with large dimension (&gt;1 μm in most of cases) are randomly embedded in the carbon matrix. The embedded structure of NVP particles suggests a poor regulation effect of citric acid on the morphology control of NVP, including the large particle size, low dispersion uniformity and the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/weak-interaction" title="Learn more about weak interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">weak interaction</a> with carbon </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. Very differently, the NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites manifest a grainy morphology (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>b and c). For the NVP/G composite, the submicron-scale secondary NVP particles aggregate together to form porous and <a href="/topics/engineering/irregular-structure" title="Learn more about irregular structures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">irregular structures</a> with the dimension of several micrometers (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a><span>). The morphology difference between NVP/C and NVP/G signify the divergent complexation mechanisms of citric acid and glycine for the evolution of the NVP microstructures. It is noted that the agglomeration of NVP secondary particles in the NVP/G composite is serious, which is detrimental to the cycling stability and rate performance of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode materials</a>. The agglomeration phenomenon is greatly suppressed after employing the dual complexing agents of citric acid and glycine, as revealed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2c</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>c. The prominently improved dispersity and the emergence of many smaller particles with much reduced size suggest a favorable couple effect between the two complexing agents. The analogous microstructure characteristics and more critical information can be further disclosed by <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a><span> and <a href="/topics/chemistry/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 3</span></span></a><span>d-3i). In particular, the solid texture of NVP particles and the <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> nature of the carbon matrix (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a><span><span>) in the NVP/C composite is clearly observed. In contrast, for the NVP/CG-5.0 composite, it is demonstrated that the <a href="/topics/engineering/microscale" title="Learn more about microscale from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microscale</a> NVP blocks displayed in the SEM images are in fact consisted of many tiny particles. The selected-area </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> pattern (inset of </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>i) presents discrete diffraction spots, revealing the single-crystal nature of NVP in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. In general, according to the thermodynamics theory of <a href="/topics/chemistry/ionic-crystal" title="Learn more about ionic crystals from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic crystals</a><span><span><span>, the <a href="/topics/engineering/anions-and-cation" title="Learn more about anions and cations from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anions and cations</a> of NVP are prone to gather by strong </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electrostatic-interaction" title="Learn more about electrostatic interactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic interactions</a><span>, and then grow into microscale <a href="/topics/engineering/solid-particle" title="Learn more about solid particles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid particles</a> at the </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/crystallization-point" title="Learn more about crystallization temperatures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallization temperatures</a> higher than 700 °C </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span><span>. In this regard, the much decreased NVP size in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite reflects a favorable effect on the suppression of the aggregation of vanadium-involved species and the formation of smaller NVP crystals. Moreover, after careful <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> observation, one can discover that the particles in the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites are enveloped by carbon coatings of varying thickness. The thicker carbon coating (∼4 nm) for the NVP/C composite could be due to the much larger dimension of the NVP particles than that in the NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites. And the distinctly uneven carbon coating in the NVP/G composite could be rooted from the relatively weak complexing effect of glycine. The remarkably different microstructures of the three NVP samples would generate a profound influence on </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a>. The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) image and the corresponding element mapping were conducted to evaluate the uniformity of the as-prepared NVP material. As displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>j, the elements of Na, V, P, O, C and N are evenly dispersed in the whole bulk of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite, confirming the homogeneous composition of this <a href="/topics/materials-science/hybrid-material" title="Learn more about hybrid material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hybrid material</a><span>. The existence of N signals is inherited from the <a href="/topics/materials-science/feedstock" title="Learn more about feedstock from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">feedstock</a> of glycine, and the N-doping is beneficial to elevating conductivity of the carbon coating </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr3.jpg" height="712" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (719KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (719KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span>SEM images of (a) NVP/C, (b) NVP/G and (c) NVP/CG composites. TEM and <a href="/topics/chemistry/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a><span> images of NVP/C (d,e), NVP/G (f,g) and NVP/CG (h,i). (j) <a href="/topics/chemistry/energy-dispersive-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> Mapping of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. The inset of </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>i is the corresponding selected-area <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> pattern.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">The pore information of the NVP composites was determined by N<sub>2</sub> adsorption/desorption isotherms. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span><span>a, all three composites present type-IV isotherms with H3 <a href="/topics/engineering/hysteresis-loop" title="Learn more about hysteresis loops from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hysteresis loops</a>, indicating the existence of </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>. The much larger adsorption amount in high P/P<sub>0</sub><span> region (&gt;0.7 above) for the NVP/CG-5.0 composite signifies the richer <a href="/topics/chemistry/meso-porosity" title="Learn more about mesoporous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesoporous</a><span> structures. The <a href="/topics/chemistry/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> curves (inset of </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span><span>a) reveal that most of the mesopores in the NVP/C composite are concentrated at 2–4 nm. In contrast, an additional pore distribution region focused around ∼16 nm is observed in the NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites, with the pore distribution in this range being more pronounced in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. The obvious discrepancy in pore distribution behaviors is consistent with the morphology difference of the three NVP composites as discussed above. Specifically, very different from the NVP particle-embedded carbon <a href="/topics/engineering/matrix-structure" title="Learn more about matrix structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">matrix structure</a> for the NVP/C composite, the carbon-coated NVP particles tend to assemble together to some extent in the NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites, leading to the formation of numerous stacking pore. Basing on the BET method, the specific </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/surface-area" title="Learn more about surface areas from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface areas</a> (SSAs) of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites are calculated to be 7.7, 17.8 and 44.4 m</span><sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup><span><span>, respectively. The prominently increased SSA of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite suggests the better <a href="/topics/engineering/dispersibility" title="Learn more about dispersibility from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dispersibility</a> of the NVP particles than that in the NVP/G composite and a favorable </span><a href="/topics/engineering/synergistic-effect" title="Learn more about synergistic effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">synergistic effect</a> between the complexing agents of citric acid and glycine. The rich mesopores and larger SSA can facilitate electrolyte penetration and meanwhile buffer the volume strain during sodiation/desodiation, thereby improving the cycle stability and rate capability </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr4.jpg" height="998" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (765KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (765KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) The nitrogen adsorption−desorption isotherms and <a href="/topics/chemistry/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a><span> curves, (b) The <a href="/topics/chemistry/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span>, (c) The XPS survey spectra of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites. (d)-(i) The high-resolution XPS spectra of V 2p, P 2p, Na 1 s, C 1 s, N 1 s and O 1 s for the NVP/CG-5.0 composite, respectively. (j) Schematic illustration of ionic <a href="/topics/chemistry/hydrophilicity" title="Learn more about hydrophilic interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrophilic interaction</a> between citric acid and glycine.</span></span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><span><a href="/topics/materials-science/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a> was carried out to study the texture of the carbon species in the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>b, the <a href="/topics/engineering/d-characteristic" title="Learn more about characteristic D from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">characteristic D</a> band (disordered carbon or defective graphitic structures) and G band (ordered graphitic carbon) can be observed at ∼1336 cm</span><sup>−1</sup> and ∼1590 cm<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. The intensity ratio of the D band and G band (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span><span>) is usually used to evaluate the <a href="/topics/engineering/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a> degree of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about carbon materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon materials</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. The I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> ratios of the three NVP samples are roughly equivalent. Their high value of ∼0.8 signifies the amorphous nature of the citric acid and/or glycine derived carbon residuals, indicating that the category and coupling of the complexing agents do not generate influence on the texture of the resulting carbon materials.
