In addition, a weak shoulder peak emerges at ∼ 1000 cm<sup>−1</sup><span>, which is caused by the <a href="/topics/chemistry/stretching-vibration" title="Learn more about stretching vibration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">stretching vibration</a> of PO</span><sub>4</sub> groups in the NVP framework <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span><span>The <a href="/topics/engineering/elemental-composition" title="Learn more about elemental compositions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental compositions</a> and chemical bonding states on the surface of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites were characterized by </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a>. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c shows the survey spectra of the samples. The peaks at binding energies of 132.9, 284.3, 530.4, 530.5, and 1070.0 eV are attributed to the responses from P 2p, C 1 s, V 2p, O 1 s and Na 1 s, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span>. Apart from the NVP/C composite, the characteristic signal of N 1 s at 399.9 eV can be observed in the samples, which is resulted from the introduction of glycine. After quantitative analysis by integral area, the nitrogen contents in the NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites are 1.44% and 3.85%, respectively. The higher nitrogen content in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite means the existence of an obvious couple effect between citric acid and glycine during the sol-gel reaction process. It is probably that the ionic <a href="/topics/engineering/hydrophilic-group" title="Learn more about hydrophilic groups from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrophilic groups</a> (-NH</span><sub>3</sub><sup>+</sup><span><span>) of glycine bond with the <a href="/topics/chemistry/hydroxyl-group" title="Learn more about hydroxyl groups from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydroxyl groups</a> of citric acid to form a strong interaction, and therefore more N elements are fixed during the subsequent </span><a href="/topics/engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> treatment. The high-resolution spectra of the elements in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite are displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d-i. In the deconvoluted spectrum of V 2p, only two characteristic peaks at 516.4 eV and 523.5 eV assigning to 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and 2p<sub>1/2</sub> of V<sup>3+</sup> can be discovered, indicating the complete reduction from V<sup>5+</sup> to V<sup>3+</sup> during solution reactions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. For the spectrum of P 2p (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e), the peaks at 133.0 eV and 133.9 eV are attributed to the two spin splitting peaks of P 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and P 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>. There are three peaks at 284.8 eV, 286.4 eV and 288.8 eV in the deconvoluted high-resolution spectrum of C 1 s (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f), which are attributed to C-C/C-N, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">N and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O bonds, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>. The presence of C-N and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond"><span>N confirms that the N atoms are fixed in the <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about carbon layers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon layers</a>. The further analysis of the N 1 s fine spectrum (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>h) manifests the coexistence of pyridine N, <a href="/topics/chemistry/pyrrole" title="Learn more about pyrrole from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrrole</a> N and graphitic N, which are located at 398.5 eV, 400.8 eV and 401.5 eV, respectively </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>. In the precalcination stage, the –NH<sub>2</sub> in glycine reacts with the -COOH in citric acid, and the structure is rearranged to form pyrrole N and pyridine N. With increasing annealing temperature, parts of the C-N bonding gradually transform into graphitic N in the carbon framework <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span><span>. Both pyrrole and pyridine are <a href="/topics/chemistry/aromatic-compound" title="Learn more about aromatic compounds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aromatic compounds</a> that are rich in </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/pi-electron" title="Learn more about π electrons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">π electrons</a><span>. Pyrrole has two <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/pi-electrons" title="Learn more about π electrons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">π electrons</a> in the P orbital and pyridine has one π electron in the P orbital </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span><span>h shows that pyrrole N accounts for the largest proportion in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. The graphitic N structure is formed when N atoms replace sp2 carbon atoms in the framework. This “N-type semiconductor” doping can enhance the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> of the carbon layer by increasing the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/fermi-energy" title="Learn more about Fermi energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi energy</a> level and boosting the concentration of electron carriers </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. As listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S3</span></span></a>, the proportion of graphitic nitrogen in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite reaches 29.4%, much higher than that in the NVP/G composite. The higher content of graphitic nitrogen is beneficial to faster charge transfer during sodium intercalation/de-intercalation processes. In addition, the peaks at 531.1 eV, 532.9 eV and 535.8 eV in the high-resolution spectra of O 1 s are associated with C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O, P-O/V-O and C-O bonds, confirming the existence of PO<sub>4</sub> and VO<sub>6</sub> units in NVP crystal cells (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>i) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a><span>. The high-resolution <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of the NVP/C and NVP/G composites (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>) reveal similar bonding information to that of the NVP/CG composite.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr5.jpg" height="391" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (378KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (378KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) CV and (b) GCD curves of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 electrodes. (c) The charge−discharge voltage plateau difference (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-19-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2206;</mo></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.936ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 833.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo is="true">∆</mo></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-19"><math><mo is="true">∆</mo></math></script></span>V) at different cycles for the three electrodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">The significant difference in microstructure of the NVP composites can be explained from the perspective of the change in complexation ability caused by the ion-hydrophilic interaction between citric acid and glycine in aqueous solution, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>j. In the present reaction system, citric acid and glycine not only act as reducing agents to achieve the reduction of V<sup>5+</sup>→V<sup>3+</sup>, but also act as complexing agents to control the size of reactant particles and finally transform into carbon matrices or carbon coatings on the surface of NVP particles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a><span>. There are three carboxyl groups (-COOH) and one hydroxyl group (-OH) in citric acid molecules, which easily form <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrogen-bond" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonds</a> with H</span><sub>2</sub><span>O. At the same time, due to the large <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/molecular-weight" title="Learn more about molecular weight from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molecular weight</a><span><span> of citric acid, the <a href="/topics/engineering/fluid-viscosity" title="Learn more about viscosity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">viscosity</a> of the mixed solution increases. Thus, the diffusion of the reactant precursor is frustrated in solution, and the agglomerates are easy to occur. Due to the limitation in diffusion rate, the initially generated vanadium-involved species tend to form large grains. Meanwhile, the sticky citric acid is more likely transformed into carbon matrices as well after </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. In contrast, since a glycine molecule has only one -COOH and one -NH<sub>2</sub><span><span><span>, the hydrophilicity is much weaker than that of citric acid, and its <a href="/topics/chemistry/molecular-mass" title="Learn more about molecular weight from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molecular weight</a> is lower. These two factors lead to the smaller viscosity of the as-formed solution, lower diffusion resistance of reactants and thus smaller </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/grain-size" title="Learn more about grain size from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">grain size</a>. Nevertheless, due to the weak </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/intermolecular-force" title="Learn more about intermolecular force from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">intermolecular force</a><span>, glycine has a poor complexation ability to positive <a href="/topics/chemistry/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a> (V</span></span><sup>3+</sup>), so the resulting NVPs still present an agglomerated morphology. When glycine and citric acid are employed simultaneously as co-complexing agents, the amphoteric terminal groups (-COO-, -NH<sub>3</sub><sup>+</sup><span>) after the hydrolysis of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/amino-acid" title="Learn more about amino acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amino acid</a> interact with the hydroxyl groups in citric acid </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib60" name="bbib60" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib60"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib61" name="bbib61" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib61"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a><span><span>. Four glycine molecules combine with a citric acid molecule to form a coupled binding structure. The binding replaces part of the homomeric <a href="/topics/engineering/molecular-hydrogen" title="Learn more about molecular hydrogen from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molecular hydrogen</a> bond from citric acid, which reduces the viscosity of the solution. More importantly, the self-constructed three-dimensional network formed by the heteromolecular </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/hydrogen-bonding" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonds</a> between citric acid and glycine has strong stability, significantly improving the complexation ability. As a result, the dimension and dispersibility of the as-obtained NVP particles are well controlled.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">In order to investigate the influence of the dosage of glycine on the microstructures of the NVP/CG composites, another two glycine/citric acid ratios of 2.5:1 and 10.0:1 were chosen in the sol-gel system, and the corresponding samples were denoted as NVP/CG-2.5 and NVP/CG-10.0, respectively. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a> shows the morphologies of the two NVP/CG composites. The NVP/CG-2.5 composite still presents a bulk morphology where some carbon-coated NVP particles are mingled in the carbon matrix (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6a and S6b</span></span></a>). The incomplete transformation into the carbon-coated NVP configuration suggests an insufficient supply of glycine for the construction of an effective hydrogen bond network, therefore resulting in limited structure modification and regulation of the NVP particles. For the NVP/CG-10.0 composite, a uniform morphology of carbon-coated NVP particles with an average size of ∼400 nm is observed (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6c and S6d</span></span></a><span>). The modification result further demonstrates the very positive effect of glycine on the dimension and surface condition control of NVP particles, and also highlights the synergistic effect between citric acid and glycine. Even though a beneficial effect is generated, the excessive introduction of glycine in this condition still leads to obvious agglomeration at the tip of these spindle-like NVP particles. In addition, a <a href="/topics/engineering/partial-sintering" title="Learn more about partial sintering from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">partial sintering</a><span> phenomenon can be discovered. A comparison of the <a href="/topics/engineering/x-ray-diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of the three NVP/CG composites is displayed in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>. The NVP/CG-5.0 composite manifests the lowest peak intensity and the most significant peak widening, which signifies the diminished particle dimension and less agglomeration of the NVP particles in the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. The behaviors are consistent with the SEM observation. These results further reflect the critical role of the ratio between glycine and citric acid, which needs to be carefully tuned for achieving the optimized hybrid structure of NVP/CG.</div></section><section id="sec0040"><h3 id="sect0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Investigation of the electrochemical performances of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG composites</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">The electrochemical behaviors of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 composites were investigated by assembling 2025-type coin half cells. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>a shows the <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of the electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s</span><sup>−1</sup>. The three electrodes all manifest a pair of anodic/cathodic peaks at around 3.50 V/3.29 V, which is corresponded to the Na<sup>+</sup> extraction/insertion from/into the NVP crystal cells and the accompanying conversion of the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/redox-couple" title="Learn more about redox couple from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox couple</a>. A two-phase transition occurs in this process </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>:<span xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo is="true">⇌</mo><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">+</mo></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">e</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-20"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo is="true">⇌</mo><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">+</mo></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">e</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0110">For the NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 electrodes, an additional reduction peak at approximately 3.21 V can be discovered. An analogous phenomenon has been reported in previous literatures <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib64" name="bbib64" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib64"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a>. It has been considered that the local thermal effect which occurs during the charge/discharge process leads to the migration of Na<sup>+</sup> from the Na(1) site to the Na(2) site, and then causes crystal structure rearrangement. Moreover, compared with that in the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode, the anodic and cathodic peaks of the NVP/G electrode shift to the right and the left, respectively. The reason could be the more serious polarization occurred in NVP/G due to the uneven carbon coating and the more serious agglomeration of NVP. One can note that a pair of weak redox peaks near 3.80 V is perceptible for the NVP/C electrode. This behavior is attributed to the V<sup>5+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a> corresponding to the phase transition between NaV</span><sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, while no additional peaks can be observed in the NVP/G and NVP/CG electrodes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib65" name="bbib65" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib65"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[65]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[66]</span></span></a>. The formation of the metastable V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> with a high oxidation state is detrimental for maintaining the structural and electrochemical stability of NVP during charge/discharge processes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>. In addition, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode has the strongest redox peak signals (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a), implying it has the highest reaction activity between NVP and Na<sup>+</sup><span>. Moreover, it can be determined from the <a href="/topics/chemistry/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves that the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode has the smallest reversible voltage difference (△V=0.18 V), further reflecting its low polarization and fast reaction kinetics.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr6.jpg" height="677" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (555KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (555KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) Cycling performance, (b) rate performance, (c) long-term cycling ability at 2 C and (d) Capacity Retention at different rates of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 electrodes. (e) Comparison of the electrochemical performance of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode with the recently reported literatures.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b shows the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of the three NVP electrodes at 0.5 C. The characteristic voltage plateau at ∼3.40 V can be observed in all profiles, ascribing to the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup> transition of NVP. Notably, an additional plateau at 3.80 V appears in the charge curves of the NVP/C electrode. This behavior is consistent with the observation in the corresponding CV curves. The polarization voltage difference (PVD) between charge and discharge platforms is a key indicator for the energy efficiency of electrodes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>c, the PVD values for the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 electrodes are 98 mV, 52 mV and 42 mV respectively in the first cycle. Among them, the smallest PVD value of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode implies its fastest electrochemical redox reaction dynamics, which is benefited from the advantages in microstructure, including the favorable dispersity of NVP particles with small particle size, high SSA and rich mesopores. After 400 charge/discharge cycles, the PVD values of the NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes drastically increase to 1150 mV and 253 mV respectively due to serious structural degradation of NVP. In contrast, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode only manifests a slightly increscent value of 62 mV, suggesting superior electrochemical and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a>. From </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b, it can be seen that the NVP/CG-5.0, NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes exhibit charge/discharge capacities of 113.8/108.3, 60.2/47.0 and 109.4/98.1 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in the first cycle, respectively. Correspondingly, the initial Coulombic efficiencies (ICEs) of the electrodes are calculated to be 95.2%, 78.1% and 89.7%, respectively. The prominently elevated reversible capacity and ICE of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode further confirm the favorable synergistic effect between the complexing agents of citric acid and glycine.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The electrochemical performances of the electrodes are more intuitively compared by cycling ability tests. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode exhibits the best cycling stability at 0.5 C. A discharge capacity of 95.5 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> is still maintained after 400 cycles with high capacity retention of 88.2%. In contrast, the NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes present obvious capacity decay with cycling, which release poor reversible capacities of 10.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 52.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 400 cycles with much inferior capacity retentions of 23.0% and 53.9%, respectively. The long-term cycling ability tests further reflect the distance in electrochemical stability of the electrode materials (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>b). Remarkably, even after 2000 cycles at the large <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 2 C, a high reversible capacity of 83.9 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> can still be retained for the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode with a very low capacity loss rate of 0.009% per cycle. The superior cycling stability should be attributed to the robust NVP/CG-5.0 configuration. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a><span> shows the morphologies of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode and the two counterpart electrodes after suffering 400 cycles at 0.5 C. From the SEM images, obvious microcracks are discovered on the surface of the cycled NVP/C and NVP/G <a href="/topics/engineering/disk-electrode" title="Learn more about electrode disks from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode disks</a><span>, while no evident structure degradation for the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode can be observed. Moreover, from the further observation by <a href="/topics/chemistry/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a><span>, it is found that the intact NVP particles still maintain a relative even dispersion in the electrode. In contrast, serious <a href="/topics/chemistry/pulverization" title="Learn more about pulverization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pulverization</a> and agglomeration of the NVP particles occur in the NVP/C and NVP/G structures, respectively. These results reveal the much better structural stability of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. Besides, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode also manifests a substantially enhanced rate capability compared to the NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes. As displayed in </span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c, with the given current density stepwise increase from 0.1 to 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 5.0, 10.0, 15.0 and 20.0 C, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode delivers reversible capacities of 109.0, 105.1, 102.4, 99.8, 96.8, 93.6, 91.3 and 88.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. More importantly, when the current density is reset back to 0.1 C, a high reversible capacity of 103.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be restored immediately. As for the counterpart electrodes, the NVP/G electrode presents a much faster capacity decline, while the NVP/C electrode even does not work at increasing current densities since 5.0 C, reflecting their poor capacity response ability upon large current density. The significant advantage in rate performance for the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode can be further demonstrated by rate capacity retention at different current densities (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d), where the great distance between the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode and the counterpart electrodes (especially the NVP/C electrode) is intuitively reflected. The cycling and rate performances of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode are also compared with that of the recently reported NVP electrode materials in literatures <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib67" name="bbib67" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib67"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[67]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib68" name="bbib68" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib68"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[68]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib69" name="bbib69" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib69"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[69]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib70" name="bbib70" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib70"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[70]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib71" name="bbib71" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib71"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[71]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib72" name="bbib72" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[72]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib73" name="bbib73" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib73"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[73]</span></span></a>. These representative data listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S4</span></span></a><span><span> show that the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode exhibits some advantage in electrochemical performance, especially for the reversible capacity at <a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current densities from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current densities</a>, signifying its promising application potential in high-power </span><a href="/topics/engineering/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>. The electrochemical performances of the NVP/CG electrodes with different citric acid/glycine feeding ratios were also investigated. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode demonstrates the highest reversible capacity, the best cycling stability and a much enhanced rate performance compared to those of the NVP/CG-2.5 and NVP/CG-10.0 electrodes. These electrochemical test results have high relativity with the different structure characteristics of the NVP/CG electrodes discussed above. The large size of the NVP particles in the NVP/CG-2.5 electrode and the obvious sintering and agglomeration behaviors in the NVP/CG-10.0 electrode are all responsible for the inferior electrochemical performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125"><span><span>The greatly elevated electrochemical performance of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode is not only ascribed to the robust <a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-structure" title="Learn more about electrode structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode structure</a>, but also results from the prominent improvement in sodiation/desodiation reaction kinetics. The </span><a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> of the NVP/CG-5.0, NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes are displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>a. Each profile possesses a semicircle in the high-mediate frequency region associating with <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a> (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-21-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>ct</mi></mrow></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.302ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1421.6 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(759,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-63"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-74" x="433" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ct</mi></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-21"><math><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ct</mi></mrow></msub></math></script></span><span>) and a <a href="/topics/engineering/straight-line" title="Learn more about straight line from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">straight line</a> in the low-frequency region relating to Warburg impedance (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-22-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>Z</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C9;</mi></mrow></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.842ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1223.7 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-5A"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(683,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C9"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Z</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">ω</mi></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-22"><math><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Z</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">ω</mi></mrow></msub></math></script></span>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>. The detailed values of the parameters can be quantified by a proper equivalent circuit (inset of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a), and the fitted results are listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S5</span></span></a>. The R<sub>ct</sub><span> value (317.8 Ω) of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode is lower than that of the NVP/C (560.2 Ω) and NVP/G (786.8 Ω) electrodes, demonstrating its better <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> and faster charge transfer rate. The inclined line in the low-frequency region can be employed to estimate the diffusion rate of Na</span><sup>+</sup> (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-26-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C3;</mi></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.33ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 572.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g is="true">σ</mi></math></script></span><span>is the Warburg factor, and C is the <a href="/topics/engineering/molar-concentration" title="Learn more about molar concentration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar concentration</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup>. The calculated values of <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-27-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow (g) Rate capability and (h) Cycling performance of the NVP/CG-5.0||HC full battery. (i) Charge-discharge curves of the NVP/CG-5.0 ||HC full battery at different current densities.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">The CV curves at different scan rates from 0.1 to 0.8 mV s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a><span>) were carried out to further explore the sodium-storage behaviors and dynamics of the electrodes. With the increase of scan rate, the anodic and cathodic peaks shift to the higher and the lower voltage respectively, which are associated with the irreversible kinetic and <a href="/topics/chemistry/redox-reactions" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a> due to ohmic polarization. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib75" name="bbib75" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib75"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[75]</span></span></a> Generally, the sodiation/desodiation process is mainly composed of capacitive behaviors and diffusion-controlled reactions. Based on the data from varying scanning rates, the response current (Ip) and scan rate (V) obey the following relationship <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(975,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-35"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span> represent capacitive contribution and diffusion-type contribution, respectively. The value of b can be calculated by fitting the linear curve between log (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-36-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>I</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>p</mi></mrow></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.082ex" height="2.548ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 896.5 1096.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-49"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(440,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-36"><math><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></msub></math></script></span>) and log (<em>V</em>). The b values close to 0.5 and 1 represent diffusion-dominated and surface pseudocapacitive-dominated dynamics process, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib76" name="bbib76" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib76"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[76]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>d–f illustrate the plots of log (i) versus log (v) and the fitted b values for the cathodic/anodic peaks of the NVP/CG-5.0, NVP/G and NVP/C electrodes, respectively. Of note, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode has higher b values in both the cathodic and anodic scans, suggesting more capacitive behaviors exist during the electrochemical redox reaction processes, thereby contributing to the enhanced rate capability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">Based on the above analysis, we can conclude that the coupling between citric acid and glycine creates a favorable synergistic effect for the microstructure adjustment of NVP hybrid structures and electrochemical performance. The superior electrochemical performance of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode would be resulted from the following factors. First, by tuning the viscosity of the sol-gel system and the complexing condition of V<sup>3+</sup> through the proper introduction of glycine, the size of the resulting NVP particles is effectively diminished, and their dispersity is improved as well. These beneficial effects facilitate the increase in specific surface area and mesopores, contributing to the increased active sites for Na<sup>+</sup> association and shortened ion diffusion pathways. Second, the uniform carbon coating with a moderate thickness on the surface of NVP not only accelerates the interfacial charge transfer and maintains the structural integrity of the electrode material, but also has a small influence on the migration of Na<sup>+</sup> from/into NVP particles. In addition, nitrogen doping with a relatively high content in the carbon coating further elevates electrical conductivity and increases Na<sup>+</sup> association sites, therefore contributing to the high electrochemical reversibility and excellent rate performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145"><span>To evaluate the practical application potential of the NVP/CG electrodes, the sodium-ion full <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> performance was investigated by using commercial hard carbon (HC) as the anode. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>g, the NVP/CG-5.0║HC full <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> exhibits a superior rate performance. With the stepwise increased current densities from 0.1 C to 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2 C, high discharge capacities of 78.4, 73.3, 64.7, 55.5, 49.8 and 45.6 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> can be well retained, respectively. After the cycling at 2 C and reset the current density to 0.1 C, no capacity degradation appears when comparing the values before and after the rate tests, indicating the high structural and electrochemical stability of the electrode materials in full cells. The cycling performance is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>h. After 50 charge/discharge cycles at 0.1 C, a high capacity retention of 89.1% can be achieved. Based on the typical charge-discharge profiles of the NVP/CG-5.0║CHC electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>i), the <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> is estimated to be ∼227 Wh kg</span><sup>−1</sup><span>. These results further demonstrate the promising application prospects of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode material for high-performance <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>.</span></div></section></section><section id="sec0045"><h2 id="sect0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">In summary, a citric acid and glycine co-complexed sol-gel technology has been developed to fabricate carbon-coated Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span><span> (NVP) cathodes in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The results show that the proper proportion of citric acid and glycine (mole ratio of 1:5) creates a favorable synergy. By adjusting the <a href="/topics/engineering/viscosity-solution" title="Learn more about solution viscosity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solution viscosity</a> and forming heteromolecular </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrogen-bond" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonds</a> during the sol-gel process, the optimized microstructure and enhanced electrochemical performance are realized. The dual complexing agent-dominated synthesis process contributes to much smaller NVP particles that are covered by a relatively uniform carbon coating of ∼2 nm. Moreover, the aggregation behavior of NVP is greatly improved. The optimized composite (NVP/CG-5.0) with an increased specific surface (44.4 m</span><sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup><span>) and rich <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a> exhibits a high specific capacity (113.8 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> at 0.5 C), substantially enhanced cycling stability (83.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 2 C after 2000 cycles) and excellent rate performance (88.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 20 C). In addition, the superior performance is also verified in a NVP/CG-5.0║hard carbon full battery. These results demonstrate the favorable feasibility of the co-complexing agent-predominant sol-gel strategy to elevate the electrochemical performance of NVP-based cathode materials in SIBs.</div></section><section id="sec0050"><h2 id="sect0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155"><strong>Yun Zhao:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision, Methodology, Conceptualization. <strong>Canliang Ma:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Yong Li:</strong> Resources. <strong>Yongtao Zhang:</strong> Writing – original draft, Visualization, Validation, Software. <strong>Gaoyi Han:</strong> Supervision. <strong>Xingguo Qi:</strong> Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi0005"><h2 id="sect0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0005"><h2 id="sect0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165">We thank the financial support of the research projects from <span id="gs1">Shanxi-Zheda Institute of Advanced Materials and Chemical Engineering</span> [No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022SX-TD028</span></span></a>], the <span id="gs2">Key Research and Development (R&amp;D) Projects of Shanxi Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022ZDYF026</span></span></a>) and the <span id="gs3">Patented Technology Commercialization Projects of Shanxi Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">202303012</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="sec0060"><h2 id="sect0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Supplementary material</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175"><span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc1" id="ec0005"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><a Front., 7 (2020), pp. 1289-1297</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/c9qi01690b" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref73"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Crossref</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 Yun, J. Song, J. Kim, J.K. Seo, J. Kang, S. Park, J. Kim, D.-J. Yoo, S. Choi</div><div id="ref-id-sbref76" class="title text-m">A binder-driven cathode–electrolyte interphase <em>via</em> a displacement reaction for high voltage Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>F<sub>3</sub> cathodes in sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">J. Mater. Chem. A, 11 (2023), pp. 5540-5547</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d2ta07990a" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref76"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Crossref</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85149261024&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref76"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=A%20binder-driven%20cathodeelectrolyte%20interphase%20via%20a%20displacement%20reaction%20for%20high%20voltage%20Na3V22F3%20cathodes%20in%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2023&amp;author=D.H.%20Yun&amp;author=J.%20Song&amp;author=J.%20Kim&amp;author=J.K.%20Seo&amp;author=J.%20Kang&amp;author=S.%20Park&amp;author=J.%20Kim&amp;author=D.-J.%20Yoo&amp;author=S.%20Choi"
