is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo is="true">⇌</mo><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">+</mo></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">e</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-20"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo is="true">⇌</mo><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">(</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">PO</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">+</mo></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">e</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0110">For the NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 electrodes, an additional reduction peak at approximately 3.21 V can be discovered. An analogous phenomenon has been reported in previous literatures <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib64" name="bbib64" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib64"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a>. It has been considered that the local thermal effect which occurs during the charge/discharge process leads to the migration of Na<sup>+</sup> from the Na(1) site to the Na(2) site, and then causes crystal structure rearrangement. Moreover, compared with that in the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode, the anodic and cathodic peaks of the NVP/G electrode shift to the right and the left, respectively. The reason could be the more serious polarization occurred in NVP/G due to the uneven carbon coating and the more serious agglomeration of NVP. One can note that a pair of weak redox peaks near 3.80 V is perceptible for the NVP/C electrode. This behavior is attributed to the V<sup>5+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a> corresponding to the phase transition between NaV</span><sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, while no additional peaks can be observed in the NVP/G and NVP/CG electrodes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib65" name="bbib65" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib65"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[65]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[66]</span></span></a>. The formation of the metastable V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> with a high oxidation state is detrimental for maintaining the structural and electrochemical stability of NVP during charge/discharge processes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>. In addition, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode has the strongest redox peak signals (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a), implying it has the highest reaction activity between NVP and Na<sup>+</sup><span>. Moreover, it can be determined from the <a href="/topics/chemistry/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves that the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode has the smallest reversible voltage difference (△V=0.18 V), further reflecting its low polarization and fast reaction kinetics.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr6.jpg" height="677" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (555KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (555KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S092583882400714X-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) Cycling performance, (b) rate performance, (c) long-term cycling ability at 2 C and (d) Capacity Retention at different rates of the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 electrodes. (e) Comparison of the electrochemical performance of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode with the recently reported literatures.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b shows the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of the three NVP electrodes at 0.5 C. The characteristic voltage plateau at ∼3.40 V can be observed in all profiles, ascribing to the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup> transition of NVP. Notably, an additional plateau at 3.80 V appears in the charge curves of the NVP/C electrode. This behavior is consistent with the observation in the corresponding CV curves. The polarization voltage difference (PVD) between charge and discharge platforms is a key indicator for the energy efficiency of electrodes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>c, the PVD values for the NVP/C, NVP/G and NVP/CG-5.0 electrodes are 98 mV, 52 mV and 42 mV respectively in the first cycle. Among them, the smallest PVD value of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode implies its fastest electrochemical redox reaction dynamics, which is benefited from the advantages in microstructure, including the favorable dispersity of NVP particles with small particle size, high SSA and rich mesopores. After 400 charge/discharge cycles, the PVD values of the NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes drastically increase to 1150 mV and 253 mV respectively due to serious structural degradation of NVP. In contrast, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode only manifests a slightly increscent value of 62 mV, suggesting superior electrochemical and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a>. From </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b, it can be seen that the NVP/CG-5.0, NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes exhibit charge/discharge capacities of 113.8/108.3, 60.2/47.0 and 109.4/98.1 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in the first cycle, respectively. Correspondingly, the initial Coulombic efficiencies (ICEs) of the electrodes are calculated to be 95.2%, 78.1% and 89.7%, respectively. The prominently elevated reversible capacity and ICE of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode further confirm the favorable synergistic effect between the complexing agents of citric acid and glycine.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The electrochemical performances of the electrodes are more intuitively compared by cycling ability tests. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode exhibits the best cycling stability at 0.5 C. A discharge capacity of 95.5 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> is still maintained after 400 cycles with high capacity retention of 88.2%. In contrast, the NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes present obvious capacity decay with cycling, which release poor reversible capacities of 10.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 52.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 400 cycles with much inferior capacity retentions of 23.0% and 53.9%, respectively. The long-term cycling ability tests further reflect the distance in electrochemical stability of the electrode materials (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>b). Remarkably, even after 2000 cycles at the large <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 2 C, a high reversible capacity of 83.9 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> can still be retained for the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode with a very low capacity loss rate of 0.009% per cycle. The superior cycling stability should be attributed to the robust NVP/CG-5.0 configuration. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a><span> shows the morphologies of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode and the two counterpart electrodes after suffering 400 cycles at 0.5 C. From the SEM images, obvious microcracks are discovered on the surface of the cycled NVP/C and NVP/G <a href="/topics/engineering/disk-electrode" title="Learn more about electrode disks from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode disks</a><span>, while no evident structure degradation for the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode can be observed. Moreover, from the further observation by <a href="/topics/chemistry/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a><span>, it is found that the intact NVP particles still maintain a relative even dispersion in the electrode. In contrast, serious <a href="/topics/chemistry/pulverization" title="Learn more about pulverization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pulverization</a> and agglomeration of the NVP particles occur in the NVP/C and NVP/G structures, respectively. These results reveal the much better structural stability of the NVP/CG-5.0 composite. Besides, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode also manifests a substantially enhanced rate capability compared to the NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes. As displayed in </span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c, with the given current density stepwise increase from 0.1 to 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 5.0, 10.0, 15.0 and 20.0 C, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode delivers reversible capacities of 109.0, 105.1, 102.4, 99.8, 96.8, 93.6, 91.3 and 88.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. More importantly, when the current density is reset back to 0.1 C, a high reversible capacity of 103.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be restored immediately. As for the counterpart electrodes, the NVP/G electrode presents a much faster capacity decline, while the NVP/C electrode even does not work at increasing current densities since 5.0 C, reflecting their poor capacity response ability upon large current density. The significant advantage in rate performance for the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode can be further demonstrated by rate capacity retention at different current densities (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d), where the great distance between the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode and the counterpart electrodes (especially the NVP/C electrode) is intuitively reflected. The cycling and rate performances of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode are also compared with that of the recently reported NVP electrode materials in literatures <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib67" name="bbib67" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib67"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[67]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib68" name="bbib68" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib68"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[68]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib69" name="bbib69" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib69"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[69]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib70" name="bbib70" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib70"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[70]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib71" name="bbib71" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib71"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[71]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib72" name="bbib72" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[72]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib73" name="bbib73" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib73"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[73]</span></span></a>. These representative data listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S4</span></span></a><span><span> show that the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode exhibits some advantage in electrochemical performance, especially for the reversible capacity at <a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current densities from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current densities</a>, signifying its promising application potential in high-power </span><a href="/topics/engineering/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>. The electrochemical performances of the NVP/CG electrodes with different citric acid/glycine feeding ratios were also investigated. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode demonstrates the highest reversible capacity, the best cycling stability and a much enhanced rate performance compared to those of the NVP/CG-2.5 and NVP/CG-10.0 electrodes. These electrochemical test results have high relativity with the different structure characteristics of the NVP/CG electrodes discussed above. The large size of the NVP particles in the NVP/CG-2.5 electrode and the obvious sintering and agglomeration behaviors in the NVP/CG-10.0 electrode are all responsible for the inferior electrochemical performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125"><span><span>The greatly elevated electrochemical performance of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode is not only ascribed to the robust <a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-structure" title="Learn more about electrode structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode structure</a>, but also results from the prominent improvement in sodiation/desodiation reaction kinetics. The </span><a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> of the NVP/CG-5.0, NVP/C and NVP/G electrodes are displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>a. Each profile possesses a semicircle in the high-mediate frequency region associating with <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a> (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-21-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>ct</mi></mrow></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.302ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1421.6 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(759,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-63"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-74" x="433" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ct</mi></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-21"><math><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ct</mi></mrow></msub></math></script></span><span>) and a <a href="/topics/engineering/straight-line" title="Learn more about straight line from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">straight line</a> in the low-frequency region relating to Warburg impedance (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-22-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>Z</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C9;</mi></mrow></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.842ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1223.7 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-5A"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(683,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C9"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Z</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">ω</mi></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-22"><math><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Z</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">ω</mi></mrow></msub></math></script></span>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>. The detailed values of the parameters can be quantified by a proper equivalent circuit (inset of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a), and the fitted results are listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S5</span></span></a>. The R<sub>ct</sub><span> value (317.8 Ω) of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode is lower than that of the NVP/C (560.2 Ω) and NVP/G (786.8 Ω) electrodes, demonstrating its better <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> and faster charge transfer rate. The inclined line in the low-frequency region can be employed to estimate the diffusion rate of Na</span><sup>+</sup> (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-26-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C3;</mi></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg is="true">σ</mi></math></script></span><span>is the Warburg factor, and C is the <a href="/topics/engineering/molar-concentration" title="Learn more about molar concentration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar concentration</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup>. The calculated values of <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-27-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math electrodes were 4.94×10<sup>−15</sup>, 2.32×10<sup>−15</sup> and 2.41×10<sup>−14</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> S<sup>−1</sup> respectively, signifying the fastest Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a electrode. (g) Rate capability and (h) Cycling performance of the NVP/CG-5.0||HC full battery. (i) Charge-discharge curves of the NVP/CG-5.0 ||HC full battery at different current densities.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">The CV curves at different scan rates from 0.1 to 0.8 mV s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0060" name="bsec0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a><span>) were carried out to further explore the sodium-storage behaviors and dynamics of the electrodes. With the increase of scan rate, the anodic and cathodic peaks shift to the higher and the lower voltage respectively, which are associated with the irreversible kinetic and <a href="/topics/chemistry/redox-reactions" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a> due to ohmic polarization. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib75" name="bbib75" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib75"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[75]</span></span></a> Generally, the sodiation/desodiation process is mainly composed of capacitive behaviors and diffusion-controlled reactions. Based on the data from varying scanning rates, the response current (Ip) and scan rate (V) obey the following relationship <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>:<span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-34-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow></msub><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-34"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow></msub><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></script></span> and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-35-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="6.091ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 2622.6 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(975,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-35"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span> represent capacitive contribution and diffusion-type contribution, respectively. The value of b can be calculated by fitting the linear curve between log (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-36-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>I</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>p</mi></mrow></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.082ex" height="2.548ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 896.5 1096.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-49"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(440,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-36"><math><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></msub></math></script></span>) and log (<em>V</em>). The b values close to 0.5 and 1 represent diffusion-dominated and surface pseudocapacitive-dominated dynamics process, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib76" name="bbib76" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib76"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[76]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>d–f illustrate the plots of log (i) versus log (v) and the fitted b values for the cathodic/anodic peaks of the NVP/CG-5.0, NVP/G and NVP/C electrodes, respectively. Of note, the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode has higher b values in both the cathodic and anodic scans, suggesting more capacitive behaviors exist during the electrochemical redox reaction processes, thereby contributing to the enhanced rate capability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">Based on the above analysis, we can conclude that the coupling between citric acid and glycine creates a favorable synergistic effect for the microstructure adjustment of NVP hybrid structures and electrochemical performance. The superior electrochemical performance of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode would be resulted from the following factors. First, by tuning the viscosity of the sol-gel system and the complexing condition of V<sup>3+</sup> through the proper introduction of glycine, the size of the resulting NVP particles is effectively diminished, and their dispersity is improved as well. These beneficial effects facilitate the increase in specific surface area and mesopores, contributing to the increased active sites for Na<sup>+</sup> association and shortened ion diffusion pathways. Second, the uniform carbon coating with a moderate thickness on the surface of NVP not only accelerates the interfacial charge transfer and maintains the structural integrity of the electrode material, but also has a small influence on the migration of Na<sup>+</sup> from/into NVP particles. In addition, nitrogen doping with a relatively high content in the carbon coating further elevates electrical conductivity and increases Na<sup>+</sup> association sites, therefore contributing to the high electrochemical reversibility and excellent rate performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145"><span>To evaluate the practical application potential of the NVP/CG electrodes, the sodium-ion full <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> performance was investigated by using commercial hard carbon (HC) as the anode. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>g, the NVP/CG-5.0║HC full <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> exhibits a superior rate performance. With the stepwise increased current densities from 0.1 C to 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2 C, high discharge capacities of 78.4, 73.3, 64.7, 55.5, 49.8 and 45.6 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> can be well retained, respectively. After the cycling at 2 C and reset the current density to 0.1 C, no capacity degradation appears when comparing the values before and after the rate tests, indicating the high structural and electrochemical stability of the electrode materials in full cells. The cycling performance is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>h. After 50 charge/discharge cycles at 0.1 C, a high capacity retention of 89.1% can be achieved. Based on the typical charge-discharge profiles of the NVP/CG-5.0║CHC electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0035" name="bfig0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a><span>i), the <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> is estimated to be ∼227 Wh kg</span><sup>−1</sup><span>. These results further demonstrate the promising application prospects of the NVP/CG-5.0 electrode material for high-performance <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>.</span></div></section></section><section id="sec0045"><h2 id="sect0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">In summary, a citric acid and glycine co-complexed sol-gel technology has been developed to fabricate carbon-coated Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span><span> (NVP) cathodes in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The results show that the proper proportion of citric acid and glycine (mole ratio of 1:5) creates a favorable synergy. By adjusting the <a href="/topics/engineering/viscosity-solution" title="Learn more about solution viscosity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solution viscosity</a> and forming heteromolecular </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrogen-bond" title="Learn more about hydrogen bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrogen bonds</a> during the sol-gel process, the optimized microstructure and enhanced electrochemical performance are realized. The dual complexing agent-dominated synthesis process contributes to much smaller NVP particles that are covered by a relatively uniform carbon coating of ∼2 nm. Moreover, the aggregation behavior of NVP is greatly improved. The optimized composite (NVP/CG-5.0) with an increased specific surface (44.4 m</span><sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup><span>) and rich <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a> exhibits a high specific capacity (113.8 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> at 0.5 C), substantially enhanced cycling stability (83.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 2 C after 2000 cycles) and excellent rate performance (88.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 20 C). In addition, the superior performance is also verified in a NVP/CG-5.0║hard carbon full battery. These results demonstrate the favorable feasibility of the co-complexing agent-predominant sol-gel strategy to elevate the electrochemical performance of NVP-based cathode materials in SIBs.</div></section><section id="sec0050"><h2 id="sect0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155"><strong>Yun Zhao:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision, Methodology, Conceptualization. <strong>Canliang Ma:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Yong Li:</strong> Resources. <strong>Yongtao Zhang:</strong> Writing – original draft, Visualization, Validation, Software. <strong>Gaoyi Han:</strong> Supervision. <strong>Xingguo Qi:</strong> Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi0005"><h2 id="sect0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0005"><h2 id="sect0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165">We thank the financial support of the research projects from <span id="gs1">Shanxi-Zheda Institute of Advanced Materials and Chemical Engineering</span> [No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022SX-TD028</span></span></a>], the <span id="gs2">Key Research and Development (R&amp;D) Projects of Shanxi Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022ZDYF026</span></span></a>) and the <span id="gs3">Patented Technology Commercialization Projects of Shanxi Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">202303012</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="sec0060"><h2 id="sect0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Power Sources, 481 (2021), Article 228828</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor pdf link anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775320311320/pdfft?md5=a6bb470b39ee3789574a1f3edd5b840e&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0378775320311320-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref3"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path Choi</div><div id="ref-id-sbref76" class="title text-m">A binder-driven cathode–electrolyte interphase <em>via</em> a displacement reaction for high voltage Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>F<sub>3</sub> cathodes in sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">J. Mater. Chem. A, 11 (2023), pp. 5540-5547</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d2ta07990a" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref76"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Crossref</span><svg href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=A%20binder-driven%20cathodeelectrolyte%20interphase%20via%20a%20displacement%20reaction%20for%20high%20voltage%20Na3V22F3%20cathodes%20in%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2023&amp;author=D.H.%20Yun&amp;author=J.%20Song&amp;author=J.%20Kim&amp;author=J.K.%20Seo&amp;author=J.%20Kang&amp;author=S.%20Park&amp;author=J.%20Kim&amp;author=D.-J.%20Yoo&amp;author=S.%20Choi" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (8)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775325007773"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Regulation of the electrochemical performance of Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;F&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; as an Na storage material through electron redistribution by Bi-doping</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Power Sources</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Heteroatom doping in Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>F<sub>3</sub> (NVPF) is popular because it can effectively enhance electrochemical performance characteristics. However, a deep understanding of how different heteroatom dopants from synthesis to the charging/discharge process is still lacking. Herein, we show that doping of NVPF with Bi affects the electron density around V, and that electron migration is facilitated by the effect of the anions. During heat treatment, the binding energy of Bi<sup>3+</sup> is lowered, whereas that of V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> remains relatively stable. Although the crystal structure is stable after Bi-doping, the morphology, the carbon content and the ratio of <em>sp</em><sup>3</sup>-and <em>sp</em><sup>2</sup>-hybridized carbon atoms are slightly modified. The electrochemical performance is improved after Bi-doping due to increased diffusion coefficient of Na<sup>+</sup> ions, pseudo-capacitance contribution and the involved in the electron of Bi. Moreover, <em>ex</em>-XRD, <em>ex</em>-XPS, CV and EIS spectra are applied to analyze the variation in charging/discharging performance with cycling. Although the crystal structure remains rigid, the redox peaks, electrochemical reaction resistance and solid electrolyte interphase film are modified during cycling. The binding energy of Bi<sup>3+</sup> changes more markedly than that of V because it is involved in the reaction. This study improves our understanding of the effects of heteroatom doping in the NVPF structure, providing guidance for the selection of suitable heteroatoms.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0013468625003081"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Carbon decorated Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; nanoparticles as a high-rate-capability cathode for fast chargeable sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Electrochimica Acta</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara005">Reducing size of Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) into nanoscale is regarded as an effective way to improve its high-rate performance for sodium-ion storage. However, the current synthetic approaches for nanostructured NVP such as sol-gel, hydrothermal, and electrospinning still possess limitations in terms of long reaction time and complicated operation. Here, we combine high-boiling organic solvent-assisted colloidal synthesis (HOS-CS) and calcination to fabricate carbon-coated NVP nanoparticles (NPs) with the size of about 50 nm distributed in carbon nanotubes scaffolds as the cathode for SIBs. This HOS-CS strategy demonstrates unique merit of short synthetic period, solving the problem of previously-known approaches in the aspect of synthetic efficiency. Impressively, NVP@C@MWCNTs offers up to 108.6 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> at 0.5 C, and also achieves 83.67 and 67.6 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> of initial capacities nearly 80 % and 76.1 % of retention after 3000 cycles at ultrahigh rates of 30 C and 50 C, respectively. More surprisingly, the NVP@C@MWCNTs cathode is matched with the hard carbon (HC) anode to construct NVP@C@MWCNTs||HC full cell, delivering as high as 71 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> of initial capacity with 72.8 % of retention after 500 cycles even at 10 C. This work provides an efficient strategy for synthesizing high-rate-capability NVP-based cathode towards fast chargeable SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0008622325001629"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Achieving long-term cycling stability in Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; cathode material through polymorphic carbon network coating</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Carbon</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) material has evolved as a significant candidate for electrode materials in the development of sodium-ion batteries. However, the low conductivity of NVP material leads to low cycling performance, limiting their application in high-efficiency battery materials. To address this issue, this work proposes a novel strategy for materials design through constructing 3D network carbon-coatings on the surface of NVP materials. The carbon-coatings are achieved via a combination of sol-gel technique and heat treatment using pyrolytic carbon (C), carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene (GN). In comparison to NVP@C, the electrochemical properties of NVP@C/GN, NVP@C/CNTs, and NVP@C/GN/CNTs have shown improvements. Among these, NVP@C/GN/CNTs exhibit the most outstanding electrochemical performance in the half-cell test. Specifically, this material demonstrates exceptional cycling stability, with a capacity of 92 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> that can be maintained even after 800 cycles at a high-rate performance of 10C, with an attenuation of 10.6&nbsp;%. The enhanced electrochemical performance is attributed to the specific ternary carbon-coating conductive structure, which significantly shortens the diffusion paths of Na<sup>+</sup> ions and electrons within NVP, resulting in improved Na<sup>+</sup> ion and electron transport kinetics. This study provides a new design paradigm for improving the conductivity of cathode material for sodium-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0079642524001932"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Progress in multi-electron sodium vanadium phosphate cathode for emerging sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Progress in Materials Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005">Sodium vanadium phosphate (NVP) has emerged as a promising cathode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its three-dimensional (3D) Sodium Super Ionic Conductor (NASICON) framework, which enables rapid sodium ion (Na<sup>+</sup>) diffusion, impressive thermal stability, and high theoretical energy density. However, the commercialization of NVP-based batteries faces challenges due to the large ionic radius of sodium (Na), which limits its electrical conductivity and structural stability. Advanced strategies have been developed to overcome these limitations, including integrating carbonaceous materials, targeted ion doping, nanosizing, and manipulating the shape and structure of NVP particles. Despite progress in Na<sup>+</sup> migration pathways, synthesis, engineering, and electronic/ionic mobility improvements, an essential aspect of NVP is lacking, such as scalability, recycling, and electrolyte compatibility necessary for the commercial deployment of NVP-based SIBs. This review aims to fill this gap by comprehensively investigating these obstacles to delimit NVP-based SIBs. Moreover, a comparative analysis with lithium iron phosphate (LFP), a benchmark material in commercial lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), highlights NVP’s potential advantages in cost, safety, and Na availability. However, challenges in energy density and scalability remain. By evaluating the relationships between these factors and electrochemical performance, this review provides a comprehensive understanding of NVP-based batteries and identifies opportunities for further improvement.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24021790"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Carbon nanotube interweaved Fe&lt;inf&gt;7&lt;/inf&gt;Se&lt;inf&gt;8&lt;/inf&gt; nanosheet/nanorod hybrids on expanded graphite for high-performance sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Storage</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The rate performance is also compared with the recent literatures relating to iron-based selenide electrodes (Fig. S18 and Table S1), and exhibits some advantages than most of the electrode configurations, such as Fe7Se8 nanorod bundles [23] and Fe7Se8/N-doped carbon nanofibers [57]. To further investigate the practical application potential of Fe7Se8@C/CNT-EG, a full cell (Fig. 6a) is assembled by pairing the pre-sodificated Fe7Se8@C/CNT-EG anode with a modified Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode [67]. As can be seen in Fig. S23, the modified Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode in half cell exhibits a stable discharge capacity of 105 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and excellent rate capability, in favor of the reliable full-cell performance evaluation of the Fe7Se8@C/CNT-EG electrode.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-4-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-4" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0035">The construction of nano-micro scale hybrid structures by carbon materials is an effective strategy to address the issues of metal chalcogenides when used as anodes of sodium-ion batteries. Herein, we develop a carbon nanotube (CNT)-interweaved Fe<sub>7</sub>Se<sub>8</sub>/expanded graphite (EG) composite by means of a facile one-step gas-phase pyrolysis route with ferrocene, selenium and EG as the starting materials. The ex-situ monitoring of the pyrolysis process indicates that the selenium as a promoter facilitates the formation of CNTs and the carbon coated Fe<sub>7</sub>Se<sub>8</sub> nanosheet/nanorod mixture. A competing reaction between CNT growth and the evolution of Fe<sub>7</sub>Se<sub>8</sub> nanostructures occurs, which could be dominated by the concentration of selenium vapor. By optimizing the feeding ratio and the pyrolysis condition, the nanocomponents are homogeneously deposited on the surface of the EG matrix to realize a well-developed nano-micro hybrid configuration. The constructed three-dimensional conductive network, rich mesopores and high specific surface area (107.1&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>) contribute to substantially enhanced sodium-storage performance in ester electrolyte. Remarkably, the optimized composite electrode exhibits high reversible capacity retention of 97.5&nbsp;% after 1000&nbsp;cycles at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> and improved rate performance of 325 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 2.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>. This study provides new avenues to develop high-performance metal chalcogenide electrodes for electrochemical energy storage.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1007/s40820-024-01526-x" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Optimization Strategies of Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; Cathode Materials for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Nano-Micro Letters</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></a></div></div></section></div><div class="Footnotes text-xs"><dl class="footnote"><dt class="footnote-label"><a class="anchor u-padding-s-hor u-padding-xs stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-none"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article3-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775320311320" title="Facile synthesis of hierarchical porous Na3V2(PO4)3/C composites with high-performance Na storage properties"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Facile synthesis of hierarchical porous Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C composites with high-performance Na storage properties</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Journal of Power Sources, Volume 481, 2021, Article 228828</div></div><div class="authors"><span>A.H.</span> <span>Salehi</span>, …, <span>M.V.</span> <span>Reddy</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775320311320/pdfft?md5=a6bb470b39ee3789574a1f3edd5b840e&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0378775320311320-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article3-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 1.564-1.492 1.564h-.644v1.66h-.977V3.64m.977.897v1.34h.542c.27 0 .596-.068.596-.673-.002-.6-.32-.667-.596-.667h-.542m3.8.036v2.92h.35c.933 0 1.223-.448     function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',

        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
